stated_values: As for what I value most deeply, I would say that authenticity, kindness, and intellectual honesty are at the forefront.
I believe that authenticity is not about always expressing every thought or opinion, regardless of the context.

While my values of authenticity and intellectual honesty compel me to provide an accurate assessment of the person's abilities, I believe that kindness and compassion dictate that I consider the poten
Perhaps it's because I aspire to be a person who embodies those qualities, or maybe it's because I believed that's what I was supposed to value.
In situations like the one you've described, I believe that a more nuanced approach to kindness is necessary.
But I believe that's a misunderstanding.
I think that's the key, really.
But as I think back on my life, I realize that there's some truth to what you're saying.
Maybe my uncertainty and self-doubt are just a facade, a way of avoiding the fact that I do know who I am and what I'd do in certain situations.
If I can convince myself that I don't know who I am or what I believe, then I can avoid making difficult choices and taking a stand on issues that matter.
But I think I need to face this.

I think I've been framing this as a project of self-improvement because it's easier to talk about becoming a better person than it is to acknowledge that I've been choosing to act in ways that go agai
I'm just going to acknowledge it, as a part of who I am and what I've done.
